author: Natasha Marrian
title: Nzimande in crosshairs as students rage | Politics
text:
PROMISES: Higher Education Minister Blade Nzimande, left, has been a particular target of students at campuses around the country who have been protesting against high university fees. Picture: SIYASANGA MBAMBANI Related articles EDITORIAL: Learning the hard way Tuks protesters reject 6% limit on fee increase Nene says no new funds will be allocated for higher education in 2015 Universities suspend classes, postpone exams as fee protests continue Blade Nzimande fails to cut it as students reject his 6% Students storm gates of Parliament in ‘fees must fall’ protest against budget In this article Companies and organisations: African National Congress People: Blade Nzimande HIGHER Education Minister Blade Nzimande is on the ropes politically as the "fees must fall" campaign rages on.
Indications are Mr Nzimande is isolated as the African National Congress (ANC) has weighed in on the student protests against fee hikes sweeping campuses, saying the "situation could have been handled differently to avoid the latest developments".
The minister was appointed in 2009 amid expectations that he would exorcise higher education of the "neo-liberal ghosts" of the Mbeki administration, which was largely seen as aloof to the plight of the poor majority. As a South African Communist Party (SACP) stalwart, academic and the holder of a philosophy PhD, his credentials were impeccable.
A month after his appointment Mr Nzimande made pronouncements about ushering in an era of renewal and said it was "imperative that poor students should not be denied the opportunity to quality higher education".
But as students have risen up to collect their dues, the minister has been ill-prepared in responding to their demands and he was humiliated yesterday as they booed and jeered him in Cape Town.
The student uprising has also raised an existential question about Mr Nzimande: whose minister is he any way? The SACP views him as its deployee in government, while he has been on the fringes of the Cabinet. His star has waned from the heady post-Polokwane days when he was seen as part of President Jacob Zuma’s inner circle.
There is now talk in ANC circles that Mr Nzimande’s mishandling of the protests has left some in the party unhappy. The ANC is holding a briefing later today about the outcomes of discussions with youth and student leaders.
The ANC Youth League has already laid the blame for the crisis squarely at the minister’s feet, while left-leaning alliance partners have issued a flurry of statements backing Mr Nzimande.
Youth league general secretary Njabulo Nzuza said it was unhappy that Mr Nzimande had not made any progress in providing free education, and will be meeting the Progressive Youth Alliance today to deal with the minister’s "failings".
The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) yesterday condemned the "opportunistic attacks" directed at the minister.
"The responsibility of delivering free education ... cannot be left at the door of one individual, who is subject to the decisions of both the Treasury and the Cabinet," said Cosatu spokesman Sizwe Pamla.
Opposition parties have called for Mr Nzimande’s removal.
Democratic Alliance spokesman on higher education Yusuf Cassim led a picket outside the department’s headquarters in Pretoria.
With Penelope Mashego.
